headline: U.S. Envoy Voices Optimism Ahead of North Korea Nuclear Summit
summary: The U.S. special envoy for North Korea concluded three days of nuclear-disarmament talks in Pyongyang ahead of the second summit between Trump and Kim, expressing confidence that progress was possible.

headline: President Trump Is Healthy, White House Physician Says
summary: A White House physician said the 72-year-old president is in very good health, following an annual exam at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.

headline: Who’s Who in Fight Between Jeff Bezos and the National Enquirer
summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos mentioned a series of people in his blog post accusing the National Enquirer of blackmail. Here is a quick look at the main characters.

headline: Coke Launches First New Flavor in Over a Decade
summary: Orange Vanilla Coke and Orange Vanilla Coke Zero Sugar will go on sale across the U.S. on Feb. 25.

headline: Elizabeth Warren’s Bigger Banks
summary: The BB&T-SunTrust merger is an attempt to compete with the giants.

headline: Florida’s Voucher Vindication
summary: New data shows how school choice lifts college prospects.

headline: Arkansas Tax Cutters
summary: Gov. Hutchinson wants to make his state more competitive.

headline: Prosecutors Weigh Whether National Enquirer Violated Earlier Agreement
summary: Federal prosecutors are examining whether the National Enquirer’s dealings with Amazon.com founder Jeff Bezos violated a nonprosecution agreement the tabloid’s publisher signed last year.

headline: Notable & Quotable: Democrats Lurch to the Left
summary: ‘We are on an out-of-control roller-coaster going 100 miles per hour.’

headline: Philly Union Boss ‘Johnny Doc’ Has an Appointment With Justice
summary: He allegedly embezzled more than $600,000 to buy Q-tips, romance novels and politicians.

headline: Fallout Spreads from Wells Fargo Outage
summary: Wells Fargo scrambled to deal with a systems problem that hampered the bank’s online and mobile banking platforms Thursday and Friday. The bank has been restoring operations and is extending branch hours to handle customer questions about the issues.

headline: Bezos vs. the Enquirer Could Be a Watershed
summary: If it means journalists start reporting on how other journalists source their stories, hooray.

headline: A Visit With Venezuela’s Interim President
summary: ‘I personally don’t believe that Russia and China are on Maduro’s side,’ Juan Guaidó says in an interview.

headline: Major Obstacles Remain to Afghan Peace, U.S. Envoy Says
summary: Zalmay Khalilzad, outlined two major sticking points between the U.S. and the Taliban, including the terms of a cease-fire and talks with the Afghan government.

headline: Maduro Calls U.S. Aid Convoy an Attempt to ‘Humiliate the People’
summary: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro, at a news conference interrupted by power outages in the crisis-hit nation, lashed out at U.S.-led plans to deliver humanitarian aid after the first cargo trucks with food and medical supplies arrived at the Colombian border.

headline: Democrats Say Some States’ Medicaid Programs Aren’t Complying With Abortion Rules
summary: House Democrats are pressuring the Trump administration to crack down on several states that a government report found weren’t fully complying with a Medicaid requirement to cover abortions in cases of rape, incest or danger to a woman’s life.

headline: ‘The Spirit of Science Fiction’ Review: Art That Opens Doors
summary: Roberto Bolaño’s works comprise an imaginary world that fans call the ‘Bolañoverse,’ united by recurring characters and references. The foundations of this cosmos are found in ‘The Spirit of Science Fiction.’

headline: ‘Midnight in Chernobyl’ Review: The Worst-Case Scenario
summary: Radioactive graphite blocks from the reactor core lay strewn on the ground. Even being in their presence for minutes could be fatal.

headline: Mattel, Hasbro Stung by Collapse of Toys ‘R’ Us
summary: Hasbro and Mattel both posted steep quarterly sales declines across most of their toy portfolios as last year’s liquidation of Toys “R” Us disrupted the key holiday season.

headline: A New Sheriff for Parkland
summary: Accountability begins after “the most avoidable mass shooting in American history.”

headline: Dow Stages Late Rally to Keep Weekly Win Streak Alive
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average pared its losses heading into the closing bell to notch its seventh consecutive weekly gain, a sign of the stock market’s resilience even in the face of heightened uncertainty.

headline: Former Union Head Sentenced to More Than Four Years in Prison
summary: Federal prosecutors said Norman Seabrook, the former head of New York City’s jail officers union, accepted bribes in exchange for steering millions of dollars of union money into a risky hedge fund.

headline: Number of Workers Striking Across the U.S. Jumped in 2018
summary: More workers were involved in strikes and other labor disputes in 2018 than at any point in the past three decades, fueled by widespread teacher protests last spring.

headline: Brazil to Toughen Mine-Safety Rules After Disaster
summary: Brazilian officials are preparing to toughen mining safety rules following a deadly disaster last month that killed more than 150 people, the mining regulator’s top official said on Friday.

headline: Bank of America CEO Compensation Rose 15% in 2018
summary: Bank of America Chief Executive Brian Moynihan received a compensation package valued at $26.5 million last year, a 15% raise from the $23 million he earned in the prior year.

headline: BB&T CEO Shows Power of Positive Thinking in $28.2 Billion Megadeal
summary: Known to espouse optimism as a leadership skill, BB&T chief executive Kelly King now faces a test of his management philosophy with the SunTrust deal the two banks are pursuing.

headline: Arconic Plans to Break Itself Apart
summary: Aluminum-parts manufacturer Arconic plans to spin off one of its two main units after rejecting a $10 billion offer for the entire company and replacing its chief executive.

headline: 23andMe’s Growth Slows
summary: Consumer genetics-testing company 23andMe’s sales growth was hit by privacy concerns last year, its chief executive said, at the same time touting the company’s drug development pipeline that she hopes will power its next phase.

headline: Tokyo to San Francisco in 5½ Hours? If All Goes Well, Yes
summary: Fifty years after the Concorde’s maiden flight, we chart its speed compared to other vehicles, both existing and in the works.

headline: U.S. Government Bond Prices Rise as Trade Concerns Grow
summary: U.S. government bond prices rose Friday amid increasing investor worries about U.S.-China trade tensions.

headline: Greece Approves Macedonia’s NATO Membership Bid
summary: Greece’s Parliament approved Macedonia’s bid to become the 30th member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, under a U.S.-backed deal that aims to help stabilize the Balkans.

headline: Bezos Security Chief Has Protected Stars for Decades
summary: Gavin de Becker, the man Jeff Bezos tapped to help determine who leaked the billionaire’s personal text messages and photos to the National Enquirer, has worked for decades as a personal secret service agent to the stars.

headline: Oil Prices Close Higher on Supply Risks
summary: Oil prices settled higher Friday as supply risks outweighed concerns over a global economic slowdown.

headline: Tight Labor Market Calls For Speedier Hiring Process
summary: Low unemployment rates mean companies can’t risking dragging out their hiring processes. If they do, staffing consultants say, they risk losing the interest of top candidates or worse: losing them to competitors who move faster.

headline: Iron-Ore Rally Continues as Vale Ordered to Evacuate Town
summary: Iron ore futures reached fresh 4½-year highs on Friday, with ongoing tumult for miner Vale extending the ferrous metal’s sharp recent gains.

headline: U.S.’s Syria Ally Supplies Oil to Assad’s Brokers
summary: America’s Kurdish-led military ally in Syria has become an important supplier of crude oil to the regime of President Bashar al-Assad, delivering crude to a broker that has been targeted by sanctions in the U.S. and European Union.

headline: Why Ralph Lauren Served Up Fashion With Coffee
summary: The brand, aiming for a younger customer, staged a relaxed, accessible fashion show—with almost everything for sale right after.

headline: Fed’s Daly Unsurprised Economy Is Growing More Slowly
summary: San Francisco Fed leader Mary Daly said on Friday it isn’t a surprise that the U.S. economy has slowed down.

headline: Early Data Show Slower Start to Tax Season
summary: The first tax-filing season under the new tax law got off to a slower start than last year and filers so far are seeing smaller average refunds, according to early Internal Revenue Service data.

headline: Photos of the Week: Feb. 2-8, 2019
summary: Brazil searches for missing people after a dam disaster, the Patriots collect another Super Bowl win, Speaker Pelosi applauds President Trump’s address, and more from The Wall Street Journal’s Photos of the Week.

headline: Lawyers for Weinstein Accusers Walk Away From Settlement Talks
summary: Talks to create a fund to compensate women who accused Harvey Weinstein of unwanted sexual conduct reached an impasse when lawyers representing alleged victims of the former Hollywood producer left the discussions.

headline: Experiment With Guaranteed Income Creates Less Stress but No Jobs
summary: A much-watched experiment in Finland failed to provide evidence that offering people a guaranteed income is the answer to some of the insecurities caused by potentially profound changes in the jobs market.

headline: Fighting Near Libya’s Biggest Oil Field Keeps Production Shut Down
summary: Military clashes near Libya’s largest oil field have made conditions unsafe and production isn’t likely to restart soon, the country’s National Oil Corp. said.

headline: A True Island Sanctuary
summary: Behind the unassuming facade of Ethiopia’s Narga Selassie church, located in the middle of Lake Tana, lies a trove of stunning religious paintings.

headline: Curiouser and Curiouser at Arconic
summary: Arconic fell short in explaining its latest shift in strategyto investors.

headline: Will This “AI Dinner Party” Be Fashion Week’s Most Out-of-Body Experience?
summary: Fashion label Rag & Bone continues to eschew the runway—and this time, an AI-hosted dinner party (turned into a conceptual video set to an original Thom Yorke song) will take its place.

headline: Italians Begin Demolishing Bridge at Center of Tragedy
summary: Italy began demolishing the remains of a highway bridge in the northern city of Genoa whose collapse last year killed 43 and exposed the perilous state of the country’s infrastructure.

headline: For Kim Jong Un, the Best Blast Protection or Nothing
summary: Photograph surfaces of North Korean dictator in a luxurious armored Mercedes-Maybach S 600, a half million dollar “Guard” model.

headline: Sprint Accuses AT&T of False Advertising of 5G Service
summary: Sprint Corp. has sued AT&T Inc. over a branding campaign that it says falsely tells customers they are receiving 5G service on their smartphones, escalating marketing wars between carriers over the next generation of wireless networks.

headline: Singapore Police Search Wirecard’s Offices
summary: Shares of Wirecard fell 16% in Frankfurt after Singapore police searched the German payments company’s offices in the city-state as part of an investigation into potential accounting irregularities.

headline: Queens of the Nile
summary: A new exhibition explores the female rulers and deities of ancient Egypt

headline: Ralph Northam and the Overlords of Outrage
summary: The Virginia governor’s racism scandal is unfolding in a climate that is increasingly intolerant of human frailty and resistant to forgiveness and rehabilitation

headline: British Actor Albert Finney Dies at 82
summary: Albert Finney, the charismatic Academy Award-nominated British actor who starred in films including “Tom Jones,” “Skyfall,” “Murder on the Orient Express,” ‘‘The Dresser,” ‘‘Under the Volcano” and “Erin Brockovich.” He was 82

headline: FDR Weighs In on the Buyback Debate
summary: Amid the Great Depression, the president warned about the ‘evil’ of companies that weren’t returning enough cash to investors. Progressives these days often argue the opposite.

headline: Mattel’s Barbie Outgunned Hasbro’s Nerf
summary: Mattel and Hasbro both survived the first holiday season without Toys ‘R’ US, but Mattel did far better relative to expectations, and its shares look more attractive.

headline: All the Fun Has Gone Out of Being a Billionaire
summary: From Bezos to Schultz, America’s richest are having an unusually tough time in the public eye. It almost doesn’t seem worth it—almost.

headline: Is Bezos’s ‘Complexifier’ a Word?
summary: His statement about the National Enquirer invokes a rare word for making things more difficult

headline: Student Loans Becoming a Retirement Issue
summary: Parents are better off dealing with the temporary tears of a teenager unable to attend a high-cost dream college.

headline: Constructal Law Faces the Deconstructalists
summary: Nature inexorably presses toward a unique goldilocks hierarchal structure for any given organization.

headline: An Old Soldier Reconsiders American War in Vietnam
summary: Many young Americans idealistically volunteered to serve in the Vietnam War. We volunteers believed we were fighting for democracy.

headline: Churchlessness Can Help New Congregations
summary: Gathering in nontraditional and nondedicated places of worship can actually engender more engagement and energy in a religious community.

headline: It’s Time to Reinvest in Our Strategic Missile Defense
summary: The Pentagon’s independent cost-estimate for developing, deploying and operating a thousand Brilliant Pebbles for 20 years was $10 billion in 1988 dollars.

headline: When a Cop Bought a Doughnut Shop, Something Surprising Happened: It Thrived
summary: Ron Joyce expanded Canada’s Tim Hortons chain to more than 1,000 outlets before agreeing in 1995 to sell it to Wendy’s.

summary: The author, most recently, of “The Allies: Roosevelt, Churchill, Stalin, and the Unlikely Alliance That Won World War II” recommends works about leaders who took the nation’s soldiers into battle.

summary: Avi Loeb, chairman of Harvard’s astronomy department, created a media maelstrom by suggesting that a mysterious space object might be from another civilization. He’s relishing the attention as a teaching moment.

headline: ‘Beyond Weird’ Review: Choosing Words Carefully
summary: The math of quantum physics isn’t very hard. But speaking about it in colloquial language is.

headline: Mysteries: The Diamond and the Hostage
summary: On the eve of the czar’s coronation, a Romanov prince is held captive by a criminal mastermind.

headline: Science Fiction: On the Edge in the Golden State
summary: Middle-aged Roy Bingham lives in a postapocalyptic California: skateboarding, drinking and playing with his dog. What went wrong with America—and with Roy’s life?

headline: ‘Stalin’s Scribe’ Review: Collaborator Laureate
summary: Mikhail Sholokhov achieved a high position in the Soviet power structure and even won the Nobel Prize in 1965. But he never wrote anything to compare with his first novel, “The Quiet Don,” and some question if he even wrote all of that.

headline: Fiction: Road Trips and Time Trips
summary: A brilliant, blackly absurdist road-trip novel set in the thick of Syria’s brutal civil war.

headline: American Media Board to Probe Bezos Blackmail Claim
summary: American Media, parent company of the National Enquirer, said its board will investigate claims by Amazon.com founder Jeff Bezos that the publisher tried to blackmail him by threatening to release embarrassing photos of him.

headline: Brazil’s Flamengo Soccer Training Ground Hit by Fire, Leaving 10 Dead
summary: A fire at the training ground of one of Brazil’s best-known soccer clubs, Flamengo, left 10 people dead and three wounded.

headline: Canada Labor Market Sizzles on Record Private-Sector Hiring
summary: Employment in Canada surged in January, led by the biggest one-month private-sector hiring spree on record, while the unemployment rate climbed on a sharp increase in the number of young people looking for a job.

headline: Stocks to Watch: Expedia, Mattel, Gannett
summary: As earnings season winds down, Expedia, Mattel, Gannett, and Skechers are among the stocks to watch Friday.

headline: Interior Secretary Nominee Says He Will Balance Energy, Environment
summary: Former oil industry lobbyist David Bernhardt, acting Interior secretary, said in an interview he can balance the interests of environmentalists against an administration that has put a priority on opening public lands to energy development.

headline: Supreme Court Denies Muslim Inmate’s Request for Imam at His Side During Execution
summary: Alabama executed a Muslim inmate late Thursday after a divided Supreme Court rejected his request for an imam to accompany him in the death chamber, rather than the Christian chaplain the state provides.

headline: How Roger Stone Entangled Himself in the NFL’s Concussion Settlement
summary: Trump’s former campaign adviser Roger Stone surfaced in an unusual conflict between lawyers representing players in a $1 billion settlement to compensate former NFL players for head injuries.

headline: Female CLO Managers Tend to Outperform Men
summary: Collateralized loan obligations overseen by women deliver better returns on average than those run by men, according to Citigroup research. The finding sheds new light on the debate about the relative lack of women in the upper echelons of the alternative asset-management field.

headline: ‘Green New Deal’ Democrats Raise Climate Change as 2020 Issue
summary: Democratic officials are pushing for a plan to quickly wean the U.S. economy off fossil fuels and dramatically overhaul the energy infrastructure. Their ideas would make climate change a central issue in the next presidential election.

headline: Chris Christie as Chief of Staff? It Almost Happened
summary: White House aides thought former New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie was a shoo-in to succeeding John Kelly as President Trump’s chief of staff in December. Then, Mr. Christie pulled himself out of the running.

headline: Big Pharma’s Big Cancer Hope Is Fizzling
summary: Drugmakers have spent heavily on CAR-T cancer treatments, but early returns on the investment aren’t looking good.

headline: Amazon’s India Site Restocked After Joint-Venture Stake Cut
summary: Hundreds of thousands of products are back on Amazon.com’s India website after it restructured its investments to get around restrictions that forced sellers to pull items from the site this month.

headline: Market Turbulence Spurs Demand for Active ETFs
summary: Rocky markets are proving a boon to active managers in exchange-traded funds, an industry long synonymous with passive investing. That is good news for ETF issuers specializing in more sophisticated strategies.

headline: The Math Behind Successful Relationships
summary: A psychologist and mathematician teamed up to craft a tool that proved to be shockingly accurate at predicting which marriages would wind up in divorce.

headline: Bond and Stock Markets Need to Talk
summary: Investors buying bonds should start checking what their colleagues in the stock market are doing. Treasury yields assume no chance the Federal Reserve will raise rates this year, even as equities have rallied.

headline: Beauty Stocks May Struggle to Keep Turning Heads
summary: Makeup companies have been outliers during a subdued earnings season for the consumer sector. Their glossy valuations will take work to maintain, though.

headline: Advertisers Warm to Fledgling Alliance of American Football
summary: A new professional football league, The Alliance of American Football, plays its first games on CBS this Saturday. However, advertisers are divided on whether the country needs more football.

headline: Carlyle Explores $1 Billion Sale of Taxi Firm Addison Lee
summary: U.S. private-equity firm Carlyle Group is eyeing the possible sale of Addison Lee in a deal that could value the London-based taxi company at around $1.04 billion.

headline: Huawei Says U.K. Software Issues Will Take Years to Fix
summary: In a response to concerns over discrepancies in software flagged by a U.K. lab, the Chinese telecom giant also said that its board of directors has signed off on a companywide overhaul of its software engineering.

headline: Police Report Slow Progress on Alleged ‘Empire’ Star Attack
summary: The Chicago Police Department is nearly two weeks into its investigation of an alleged attack on Jussie Smollett, a star of the TV hit “Empire,” and has gathered little traction in finding the perpetrators.

headline: Don’t Let Uber and Lyft Take You for a Ride
summary: This year’s most anticipated IPOs will hinge on whether investors believe the ride-hailing companies can stop burning money.

headline: Japan Inc. Finds a New Use for Cash—Giving It Back to Investors
summary: SoftBank’s recent tech investments may have had a mixed record, but this week it managed to turn $5.5 billion into $15 billion in just one day—simply by announcing a plan to buy its own stock. Other Japanese companies should take note.

headline: The Rally in Emerging-Market Currencies Needs More Fuel to Continue
summary: Most currencies in developing economies have enjoyed a strong start to the year. Concrete action may be necessary for the rally to continue.

summary: What’s News: World-Wide

summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Lawmakers Close In on Deal in Talks on Border Funding
summary: Negotiators signaled they were zeroing in on a compromise spending package that boosts funding for border barriers and related security measures, with the goal of reaching a bipartisan deal early next week and avoiding a new government shutdown.

headline: Second Woman Accuses Virginia Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax of Sexual Assault
summary: Virginia Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax was accused by a second woman of sexual assault, deepening the crisis embroiling the state’s Democratic leadership.

headline: Acting AG Whitaker Faces House Grilling Over Russia Probe
summary: Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker testified that he hasn’t interfered in the special counsel’s Russia investigation and hasn’t shared information about it with the president or top White House officials.

headline: Amazon Reconsidering Plan to Put Campus in New York City
summary: Amazon executives are re-evaluating a planned campus in New York City, people familiar with the matter said, turning up the heat on local officials who have rallied opposition to giving billions of dollars in tax incentives to one of the world’s most valuable companies.

headline: The French Philosopher Who Loves America
summary: Bernard-Henri Lévy describes theas a ‘crisis of liberal democracy’ and Trump as an ‘epiphenomenon’ of American ‘retreat.’

headline: Quebec Muslims Seek to Move Past Deadly Mosque Shooting
summary: Two years have done little to heal the scars left by a shooting that killed six people at a mosque in Quebec City, Canada, as the self-confessed gunman faces sentencing.

headline: The First Money Lesson to Teach Your Children: This Is What a Dollar Looks Like
summary: In a world where purchases play out in swipes and clicks, the notion of cash as a medium of exchange can get lost on some children; ‘it’s not something they see’

headline: States Are Shifting Farther Apart on Abortion
summary: Conservative and liberal states are pulling farther apart on the issue of abortion in response to a growing sense that the Supreme Court could curb a woman’s right to the procedure.

headline: Saudi Arabia Sought Vice’s Help to Reshape Its Image and Battle Rivals
summary: Saudi Arabia is seeking to build an international media empire to combat the kingdom’s rivals and remake its image in the West, and it sought a partnership with Vice Media as part of the project, according to people familiar with the efforts.

headline: Bezos Accuses Tabloid of Blackmail; Publisher Says It Acted Lawfully
summary: Jeff Bezos accused National Enquirer parent American Media of trying to blackmail him. The publisher said it acted lawfully in the reporting of the Bezos story but that it will investigate the claims.

headline: The Long, Hard Road to Democracy
summary: Those worried about today’s setbacks should look to European history, which shows that democratic development always proceeds in fits and starts.

headline: Preparing for a Good End of Life
summary: The best way to achieve a peaceful death is by planning ahead and enlisting the help of loved ones.

headline: Crank Up the Flavor: Leftover Rotisserie Chicken Recipes
summary: Take a fresh look at yesterday’s bird. These easy Vietnamese recipes use every delicious bit.

headline: A Pedophile Doctor Drew Suspicions for 21 Years. No One Stopped Him.
summary: The federal government’s Indian Health Service failed to protect Native American boys from Pat Weber’s sexual abuse, despite repeated warning signs. The investigation found that the agency tolerated a number of problem doctors because it was desperate for medical staff.

headline: ‘Hitler’s Pawn’ Review: Who Was Herschel Grynszpan?
summary: “I must protest so the whole world hears my protest,” Grynszpan wrote to his parents. On Nov. 7, 1938, he took a gun, walked into the German embassy in Paris and killed a diplomat. The event helped prompt the Kristallnacht attacks two days later.

headline: ‘Ben Hecht’ Review: A Difficult Man to Pin Down
summary: Journalist, playwright, screenwriter, contrarian. Then, suddenly, a militant Zionist. What made Ben Hecht tick?

headline: ‘The Making of The Wind in the Willows’ and ‘The Man in the Willows’ Review: The River and the Wild Wood
summary: In May 1904, Kenneth and Elsie Grahame were late to a dinner party because, according to a maid, Kenneth was “up in the night-nursery telling Master Mouse some ditty or another about a Toad.” Master Mouse was the family name for the Grahames’ only child, Alastair, and the story that his father concocted that night was destined to become a children’s classic.

headline: House Democrats to Probe How Trump’s Associates Influenced the VA
summary: Democrats are beginning an investigation into how three men affiliated with President Trump, but who held no official government positions, wielded influence at the Department of Veterans Affairs.

headline: High-Rollers Cool Bets as Chinese Economy Slows
summary: A run of good fortune for top casino operators is coming to a halt. Industry analysts are bearish on prospects in Macau, the world’s largest gambling hub.
